'Serenity' (2019) 
"Baker Dill is a fishing boat captain who leads tours off of the tranquil enclave of Plymouth Island. His peaceful life is soon shattered when his ex-wife Karen tracks him down. Desperate for help, Karen begs Baker to save her -- and their young son -- from her abusive husband. She wants him to take the brute out for a fishing excursion -- then throw him overboard to the sharks. Thrust back into a life that he wanted to forget, Baker now finds himself struggling to choose between right and wrong." I've never watched a movie so insane, mind-boggling, utterly pretentious and yet unaware of its own illogic all at the same time. 'Serenity' is really unlike any movie I've ever seen. I was aware of its reputation and apparent awfulness before I went in, so I was simply expecting something so bad that I could laugh at and manage to have at least good time with it in that regard. Yet instead of laughing, I found my jaw-dropping at the complete lunacy and absurdity of the plot throughout the entirety of viewing. Later in this review I'll do something I never do, and that's go into spoilers. The plot-twist in this movie is so ridiculous and insane that I just have to talk about it. Until I get to that, it'll remain spoiler free. 'Serenity' fails at almost everything a film should do correctly. Its set-up is really bad, characters are unlikable, camerawork and editing can be laughable at times, and as I said the plot deep-dives into utter nonsense about halfway through the movie. I don't know how this story got green-lit or how any of these ideas came into fruition; all I know is that this is something that exists... If you read the description of the movie, and/or watched the trailer, it seems like a pretty straight-forward thriller/drama. It's not showing you how insane it really is. I've really never seen anything like this. I don't know what possessed Matthew McConaughey to sign onto this, or if he even read the full script. He's the most entertaining thing about the film, but that's just because he's basically doing his Matthew McConaughey shtick. As for Anne Hathaway, I truly like her as an actress but it saddens me to say that her acting is really bad here. I guess that might be due to the script they were all given, which overall was just very dumbed-down and lazy writing. Before I get into spoilers, I lastly want to say how shocked I was to find out this was directed by Steven Knight. If you're unaware of this man, he directed a film called 'Locke'. I absolutely loved that film and still think it's a near-flawless hidden gem. I just can't fathom how that same director could go from the genius and competence of 'Locke', to the complete polar-opposite and the mess that is 'Serenity'. Now let's get into those spoilers, you're in for a treat. SPOILERS AHEAD - If you have a random desire to ever watch this film, or be surprised at its insanity first-hand, this is your warning.
So, basically it's all just a video game... That's right... Our lead, Matthew McConaughey, is being controlled by his young son from another life, who is apparently a prodigy computer-game creator, and everyone that you've been watching in the movie is all just mere computer-code written up, so that the son can escape from his miserable reality and that he can fantasize about killing the deadbeat who abuses him and his mother every day in real-life... You just can't make this up... My head honestly hurts right now at just how crazy it all really was. Any time this embarrassment of a plot-twist was hinted at throughout the movie, I couldn't help but physically shake my head. I can at least say however, it was really entertaining to watch McConaughey descend into insanity after learning of what his own existence in the film really was. It goes so bash*t crazy about halfway through, that it's at least entertaining in that regard. Overall, 'Serenity' is a ridiculous film that is so full of itself and thinks it's a deep, metaphorical mystery, and will blow your mind; but not at how "woke" it is, rather due to your sheer inability to comprehend how it got made. I feel like they were wanting to be the next 'Matrix', in regards to the plot and wanting to make us question our own reality, and yet failed so miserably. Thinking about it now, I could honestly see myself throwing this film on again in the future, just so I could see the reactions of whoever else I'm watching it with. It's still a really bad movie, yet so insane that I can at least appreciate it in a guilty-pleasure aspect.

My Rating - 2/10

If the point was to make it all feel a little off-kilter, it succeeded, that doesn't make it an easy watch because of it.

OK fine! It would have been the kind of thing I would have written at university and maybe even tried to love if I had seen it at the cinema at 19, but now? It's a waste of McConaughey and Knight's talents and it's a bit of a cringe-fest and a lot of a joke.

Recreational fishing boat captain Baker Dill is approached by his ex-wife to kill her abusive husband.  It's an interesting premise, and the film has a moody, surreal atmosphere that is initially intriguing.  That intrigue dissipates quickly.  One problems is that the characters are never clearly defined, ranging from relatively bland to unappealing.  The movie fails completely due to the last minute reveal that makes practically everything that preceded it irrelevant.  Instead of feeling surprised, viewers will rightly feel cheated.

I always love when an original concept makes it to the big screen, but sadly, not every original idea will resonate with every viewer. In the case of Serenity, it seems as though many people have chosen to be detached from it in terms of relatability. I admire when filmmakers go out of their way to create a bizarre world that usually would not work, but goes for it anyways. Unfortunately, Serenity is one of the strangest films I have seen in quite some time and also one that I feel is quite terrible as a whole. Although there was an effort to impress here, it failed on many levels and here is why.

After a burnout fisherman is approached by his ex-wife, his new mission turns into whether or not he is okay with murdering her new husband, due to his violence toward her and their son. That premise alone works as a movie, but that is about as much as I can say without ruining where the film takes a turn. This is where I admire the filmmakers for trying, even though it did not work at all. The twist that this film delivers may work for a handful of people, but I fear that viewers will most likely laugh once the film reveals what it is truly about.

Matthew McConaughey is a fantastic actor and has truly proven his worth throughout the past decade or so. Nominated for numerous awards and appearing in Oscar-nominated films consistently, I always look forward to the next project he chooses to sink his teeth into. While I will not say his performance is fantastic here, he is definitely committed from start to finish. He carries this movie in a dramatic way, but his wacky character feels a little fake at times. He is quite over-the-top here and it almost stood out as a negative to me.

On top of this crazy performance, as I mentioned, the twist this film delivers is one of the best and worst twists I have witnessed in years. There is a sense of humour to it for the viewers, but the movie takes everything so seriously that it really collapsed as a whole. This film would have had a lot of potential if it winked at the audience, but it just asked you to buy into the entire premise as if it were real. This aspect of the film alone is what turned me off. I enjoyed watching this film in a weird way, but that does not mean I actually liked the film.

In the end, Serenity is a great film to watch if you are a film lover and have someone to watch the film with, while having a few drinks. There were times when I had to question how these filmmakers thought certain plot devices were going to work for the majority of moviegoers because it simply feels ridiculous when the true storyline kicks in. Serenity may end up being on my list of films to never watch from 2019, but it certainly is a memorable one, so take from that what you will.

The audacity.  So this is about a tuna fisherman (Matthew McConaughey).  He just wants to keep to himself, make enough money to get by and drink some rum at the end of the day.  All that is about to change when a woman from his past (Anne Hathaway) shows up and offers him $10 million to murder her husband on a fishing trip.  Now I like the cast of this, but there was nothing about the posters, trailers or even word of mouth that made want to see this.  It wasn't until I actually listened to a negative review that my interest spiked.  To explain, I was told that you had to see it to believe it, because this has a twist that would put M. Night to shame in the worst way possible.  Well, in that regard, I have to say: I got exactly what I came for.  I will not get into spoilers here, because that's not the type of blog that I run over here, but good LORD, this is the type of movie that makes you want to call up an old friend and talk about what they try to pull.  I don't remember the last time I saw a movie even attempt something like this, and if there was more than just one other person in the theater I saw this in, I am fairly certain I would have seen people walking out when it shifts from the second to third act.  Here's what I think happened: I think that McConaughey's agent didn't actually read the full script, maybe skimmed it at best.  Contracts were signed because it was an exotic shooting location, and then other people got onboard with it once they saw that he was involved.  I don't think it is a spoiler for me to say that there is a twist involved; for the entire first hour, they are laying down breadcrumbs that there is a reveal coming.  You just don't know the extent of it, and if you thought what they pulled in Adrift was bad, you have not seen anything yet.  I apologize that this is all that I can talk about, but if you actually watch this, I promise you: this will be all that you will want to talk about as well.  What is wild to me is that this doesn't start off all that bad.  Sure, it is derivative to Moby Dick, but it holds your attention because there are decent actors on the screen.  But once you get to that reveal, it just nosedives like a plane crash.  If you watch bad movies on purpose or like to see the extent of how bad writing can fail, then I have to give this a big recommendation.  For everybody else, it is something that you should avoid if you can, because you're going to walk away angry.

"Serenity" deserves real interest and support.  Not because it's a perfect movie - very few are, this one certainly is not.  It deserves attention for playing with genre stereotypes and nudging boundaries in a truly interesting way.

In 2013, Writer/Director Steven Knight was applauded by critics for "Locke."  In that film, with the exception of the opening scene, all the action takes place inside a car during a long drive to London.  In "Serenity," Knight spends the first half of the movie putting a blockbuster cast through its paces to set up a fairly conventional film noir.  He then spends the remainder turning the genre inside-out, offering a bit of existential introspection (do any of us truly know anything?) and providing some thoughts about the consequences of domestic violence.

Presumably because of the film's lofty aspirations, Knight has been able to assemble a powerhouse cast.  Baker Dill (Matthew McConaughey) is a dissolute fishing boat captain, traumatized by war and seeking solace at the end of the world.   Soon enough, his ex-wife (Anne Hathaway) arrives with a typically noirish proposition:  if Dill will take her abusive husband (played powerfully by Jason Clarke) on a one-way fishing expedition, Dill can have the husband's $10 million in ill-gotten gains.  Diane Lane makes an odd appearance as a very-part-time love interest and neighborhood watch lady.

McConaughey's performance, which carries the film, is a slow burn.  Early on, he is portrayed as a man burying his anger, trauma, resentment and pain in booze, with all the enigmatic enthusiasm he brings to selling Lincoln Navigators.  As the plot develops (thickens, curdles, insert your own verb here), McConaughey's intensity ratchets up appropriately, to a very satisfying climax.

Busting genres is not for the faint of heart.  Professional critics have generally savaged this film.  In my view, they are wrong.  This is a very imperfect film.  Beyond Baker Dill, none of the characters are developed in a meaningful way.  The existential "reveal" in the middle of the film offers an array of thematic options, none of which are pursued fully.  Despite its failures, this movie deserves a thoughtful, engaged audience.  These days, films waste too much time playing it safe - too many superheroes, too many mind-numbing sequels.  There are too few films that, like "Serenity," are willing to take real chances.

There are many nuances such as camera angles, lighting, and props that all feel out of place in such a genre flick because they are tells eluding to what the film is actually about. These aren't getting much discussion. For me, this reveal deepened the motivations and purpose of the film much more so than other more well loved twists. Shutter Island comes to mind as one such highly praised twist that ultimately adds little to the story. 

As much as I am defending the movie, I must admit that Serenity is far from perfect. Its biggest sin is the fact that the main character of the real story gets very little screen time. The absence of their perspective from the start results in an experience that can easily be read as dishonest and nutty. Were the plot and twist identical, but this seemingly minor character got much more focus from the beginning, I am convinced that this film would be heralded as genius and praised among the greatest of topsy turvy outings.

If somebody told you that you were seeing a movie with Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, and Jason Clarke, you'd be expecting a decent movie. All of these actors on their own have had brilliant movies, so it's not a stretch to expect something better than what Serenity delivers.

There's a twist in the movie that I won't ruin for anyone. I'll just say that the twist ruins the movie. The initial concept presented in the first 45 minutes actually shows potential. It's a shame that the filmmakers didn't explore that path. Instead, they tried some twist that made it feel like a rejected M. Night Shyamalan movie idea.

The movie gets annoying near the end. You feel like this movie thinks it's way more clever than it really is. These "thriller" movies with the big twist in the end can be a high-risk formula. When they work, people absolutely love the film for fooling them with such a clever story. When they fail, it ruins everything the movie had been working for in the last hour.

I'm only giving it a three because the initial concept had promise and I'm a fan of the lead actors in this film. Perhaps they each received some bad advice from their people before signing on for this movie.

I'll leave you with this. There's a few sex scenes in this movie. You won't think too much about them at first. But once the twist is revealed, you'll think back in the theater lobby that those sex scenes were really messed up.

My advice is to save yourself a trip to the theater. It's worth a rental from Redbox in a few months. The laugh you'll get from how bad the ending is will be worth the buck and change.
